Mittelmeijer-Hazelegera, Jack G. Nazloomians, Leendert H. Staals,b,* Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Amsterdam, Nieuwe Achtergracht 166, 1018 WV Amsterdam, Netherlands bUnipath Ltd., Norse Road, Bedford MK41 OQG, UK (Received 3 November 1993, revised manuscript received 12 January 1994) Abstract The activity and selectivity of silica-supported copper catalysts in the hydrogenolysis of methyl acetate were studied in relation to the structure of the active phase. The activity was found independent of the copper loading, when the weight of copper in the reactor was kept constant. Copper catalysts were prepared by homogeneous precipitation. In the range of reduction temperatures between 543 K and 743 K, the activity was constant, in spite of considerably different copper metal surface areas. The absence of a correlation between activity and copper surface area is assigned to the formation of highly dispersed copper not active in methyl acetate hydrogenolysis. In contrast to the equal activity, catalysts of low copper loading produced more ethane than the higher loaded catalysts, based on the weight of copper. A remarkable parallel between the amount of ammonia chemisorbed on the reduced catalyst and the ethane selectivity suggests that a dehydration reaction to ethene on acid sites located at the silica support, followed by hydrogenation on the copper metal phase, is responsible for the formation of ethane. Key words: acid sites; ammonia; chemisorption; copper/silica; ethane formation; methyl acetate hydrogenolysis; reduction temperature; selectivity (ethane); surface area 1. Introduction The hydrogenolysis of esters is an important reaction in the synthesis of fatty alcohols from fatty acid methyl esters. Fatty alcohols are widely used as base chemicals for the *Corresponding author. Tel. ( +44-234) 347161, fax. ( +44-234) 218781. 0926-860X/94/$07.00 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSD/0926-860X (94)00005-C 64 F.Th. van de Scheur et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 111 (1994) 63-77 production of surfactants and at present the synthesis route from fatty acid methyl esters is becoming more and more favourable with respect to the petrochemical process starting from ethylene [ 1 ] . The consumption of oleochemical-based alcohols is expected to increase from 530 000 MT in 1990 to 800 000 MT in 1995 [ 1 ] . Closely connected with this growing demand are ongoing searches for improved processes working at pressures below 100 bars [2] and active copper-based catalysts without chromium [3]. For catalytic studies, methyl acetate is a suitable model compound for the C12-C18 esters of industrial interest. The hydrogenolysis reaction equation can be described by: CH3-CO-O-CH3 +2H2 Z:-2 CH3-CHz-OH+CH3-OH In addition to the main products ethanol and methanol, a large number of other compounds can be formed, depending on the process conditions. Concerning the quantity of side products, ethyl acetate, ethanal and ethane are the most important. Ethyl acetate is formed by a transesterification of the product ethanol with methyl acetate and it is merely an intermediate in the reaction that reacts with hydrogen to two equivalents of ethanol. Ethanal formation is strongly dependent on the temperature and proceeds either by an incomplete hydrogenation of the ester or by dehydrogenation of ethanol. Since the latter side reaction does not occur at high pressure it is considered to be less relevant to the current study. From a practical point of view, the study of ethane formation is very important, as minimizing the amount of alkanes is a key objective in an industrial fatty alcohol synthesis process. More than the process conditions, the properties of the catalyst play an important role in the ethane selectivity. In earlier work on copper-chromite catalysts, several factors promoting alkane formation were the subjects of research [ 4 ] . Nowadays, alternatives for copper-chromite catalysts are subject of extensive research and copper-silica-based catalysts have been described both in patents [5-7] and in the scientific literature [8-10]. However, little is known about the specific mechanism of alkane formation. This work is therefore aimed at a better understanding of the ethane formation in the methyl acetate hydrogenolysis, in relation to the texture and other surface properties of silica-supported copper catalysts. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalyst preparation and copper metal assay Silica-supported copper catalysts were prepared by homogeneous precipitation of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Merck) onto silica (Shell S980A) particles, according to a method earlier described by Van der Grift et al. [ 11 ] . At 363 K, the pH of a suspension containing silica and copper nitrate was raised homogeneously from 3 to about 6.5 by decomposition of urea (Aldrich). The copper loadings of the catalysts were determined by quantitative measurement of the hydrogen consumption in temperature-programmed reduction and by inductively coupled plasma atom emission spectrometry (ICP/AES) and are given in Table 1. Ammonia adsorption The experiments were performed in a glass vacuum system for chemisorption equipped with a turbo-molecular pump that could normally reach vacuum pressures between 0.1 and 1 mPa. About 50 mg of catalyst precursor was placed between two plugs of quartz wool in a 20.6 cm 3 Pyrex glass reactor suitable for pretreatment and adsorption. Samples were pretreated in-situ by a calcination in 0.5 cm' s-' of air, with a temperature program of 0.02 K s--` to 753 K and a dwell at this temperature for four hours. Reduction was carried out in a flow of 0.5 cm3 of hydrogen (Praxair 99.9999%) by heating with 0.02 K s-' to 643 K and a dwell for one hour. After the reduction, the reactor was evacuated at 643 K for 30 min and cooled down to ambient temperature under vacuum. Adsorption experiments were conducted at room temperature by the admission of a known amount of ammonia (200, 300, 400 or 500 mbar, Praxair 99.96%) to a glass chamber with a calibrated volume of 31.1 cm3 After stabilization for one hour, the gas was expanded to the previously evacuated reactor. Again after a stabilization time of one hour, the adsorption pressure was determined. The overall amount of adsorbed ammonia that could be calculated from the expansion pressure was always corrected for the adsorption on the glass of the reactor, which was determined by blank measurements. In most cases the glass adsorption did not exceed 20% of the value of the adsorption on the catalyst. The amount of chemisorbed ammonia was determined by extrapolation of the amounts of ammonia obtained at different expansion pressures top = 0. Regeneration after ammonia adsorption was performed by heating at 0.1 K s-' to 643 K in a hydrogen flow of 0.5 cm' s-'. At 643 K, the reactor was evacuated for 30 min and subsequently cooled down to room temperature. 2.5. Activity measurements Activity measurements were performed in a standard flow system for catalyst testing. Appropriate amounts of catalyst, sieve fraction 125-212 jcm, and silica diluent (Shell S980A), were put into a U-tube Pyrex glass reactor with an inner diameter of 5 mm. Samples were calcined in 1 cm' s-' of air, with a temperature program of 0.02 K s-' to 753 K and FTh. van de Scheur et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 111 (1994) 63-77 67 a dwell at this temperature for twelve hours. Reduction was carried out in a flow of 1 cm' of hydrogen (Praxair 99.999%) by heating with 0.02 K s-' to 643 K and a dwell for one hour. A mixture of 0.25 vol.-% of methyl acetate, 10 vol.-% HZ and nitrogen as the balance was used as the feed to the reactor at a flow-rate of 2 cm3 NTP s-' and an absolute pressure of 4 bars. The W/F was 1.5 . 103 kg cat. s mol' and the isothermal stabilization time between two subsequent samples was 30 min. Samples taken by means of an 8-way Carle valve were analyzed on a Chrompack 438A gas chromatograph equipped with a HayeSep S 1 / 8 in. stainless steel column, thermal conductivity detector and flame ionization detector. The signals were integrated by a Milton Roy CI-10 integrator and the data were collected on an IBM AT computer. FID response factors were found to agree with those published by Ackman [ 14 ] . 3. Results and discussion In order to study the effect of the copper loading on the formation of ethane, activity measurements were performed with a constant weight of 20.7 mg of copper in the reactor. Silica was added as a diluent to obtain an equal bed length independent of the copper loading. The experimental quantities are given in Table 3. Fig. 1 displays the results of the activity measurements after a standard reduction at 643 K for one hour. The series of measurements at descending temperature were chosen as a hysteresis had been observed [ 3 ] . In overall comparison, the activity at a constant copper weight in the reactor appears to be independent of the copper loading in the catalyst, although at more detailed inspection the lower-loaded catalysts seem to be slightly more active. However, larger differences were found for the ethane selectivity of the corresponding measurements, which has been depicted in Fig. 2. Ethane formation proceeds relatively more rapidly for catalysts with lower copper loading. The 4 wt.-% CU/Si02 catalyst shows the highest and the 26 wt.-% CU/Si02 the lowest selectivity to ethane. Mass transfer limitations cannot be the cause of this phenomenon, as the mean pore diameter decreases from about 12 nm for the 4 Wt-- /0 Cu/Si02 catalysts to about 4 nm for the 26 wt.-% catalyst (see Table 2) . If this effect were dominant, overhydrogenation to ethane would be favoured by a more fine pore structure. Then the highest ethane formation would be expected for the 26 wt.-% catalyst. Aiming at the establishment of a relation between the active phase and activity and selectivity, the copper surface area was determined. The copper metal surface area of the six catalysts shows a linear proportionality to the copper metal loading, both after reduction at 543 K and after reduction at 643 K. This is shown in Fig. 3. This implies that they have a uniform structure independent of the copper loading and that the dispersion of higher loaded catalysts is not lower than that of the lower loaded catalysts. Moreover, the linearity means that at a constant weight of copper, there is also about an equal copper surface area in the reactor. The 26 wt.- % Cu/Si02 was taken for studying the effect of the reduction temperature on the copper surface area of the catalyst. Fig. 4 displays the reduction profiles of this catalyst reduced at two different reduction temperatures, namely 543 K and 643 K. In both cases the heating rate was 0.02 K s-' and the time at the final temperature was one hour. A sharp maximum in the rate of reduction is observed at 431 K and a maximum in the second stage of reduction is found at 513 K. The weight loss maxima occur at relatively low temperatures which is probably caused by the size of the sample and the poor heat transfer in the thermobalance. There is only a small increase in the degree of reduction between these two reduction temperatures. Nevertheless, the copper surface area after reduction at 643 K was reproduced with high accuracy, which confirms that the observed increase in surface area is real. This considerable increase in copper surface resulting from only a modest increase in the degree of reduction can be explained by the formation of highly dispersed copper crystallites with a fraction exposed approaching unity. Another explanation might be that water produced by the reduction reaction that is difficult to remove from the pores of the catalyst has an effect on the degree of surface reduction. Above 643 K, no further increase of the copper surface occurs, but instead somewhat smaller values are measured. There is thus clearly a change in the morphology of copper in the range of reduction temperatures between 543 K and 743 K, and a maximum in copper surface area after reduction at 643 K. In spite of the significant dependence of the copper surface area, changes in the reduction temperature between 543 K and 743 K do not result in an increase or decrease in the activity of the 26 wt.-% CU/Si02 catalyst (see Fig. 6). Kohler et al. [9], using quantitative measurement of the product desorption from Cu/ Si02 catalysts concluded that one adsorbed acetyl fragment occupies at least four, but more likely twelve surface copper atoms. Van der Grift et al. [ 15 ] ascribed the decrease in activity of a 20 wt.-% CU/Si02 after reduction at 823 K to the creation of more densely packed copper surfaces, which were thought to be less active than the more open surfaces created at 573 K. These two phenomena are strong indications for structure sensitivity. The necessary ensemble size for the decomposition of nitrous oxide is at least two copper atoms. Since the copper reduced between 543 K and 743 K can be measured by nitrous oxide but does not contribute to the activity, the island size of the dispersed copper formed in this stage of the reduction must be between two and twelve copper atoms, whereas a disordered structure may be an additional explanation for inactivity. The sites for ester hydrogenolysis are clearly situated on the copper that is reduced below 543 K and the highly dispersed copper metal formed in the reduction stage between 543 K and 743 K does apparently not contribute to the activity of the catalyst. Moreover, there appears to be no direct connection between the extent of the copper area and the activity. In this respect, there is no analogy with the methanol synthesis where such a relationship has been proposed [16]. In agreement with the experimental approach in the activity measurements in which the amount of copper was maintained constant while the copper metal loading was varied, the amount of chemisorbed ammonia could also be calculated per unit weight of copper. In Fig. 8 these values are shown as a function of the copper content of the catalyst. The normalized ammonia uptake is clearly higher at low copper loadings than at high copper loadings. Comparing this observation in Fig. 8 with the ethane selectivity displayed in Fig. 2, there seems to be a parallel between the ammonia uptake and the formation of ethane. The formation of hydrocarbons in the hydrogenolysis of fatty acid methyl esters was already a well-known problem at the time that copper-chromite catalysts were most frequently used in this reaction. The reactor temperature should be maintained as low as possible in order to prevent this undesired side reaction [4]. Coenen [21J explained the alkane formation from two consecutive reactions, namely the dehydration of fatty alcohol to a primary alkene, followed by hydrogenation to alkane. Silica-supported copper catalysts have also been reported to give alkane formation. Van Beijnum [22] observed ethane formation in the hydrogenolysis of methyl acetate on a catalyst prepared by homogeneous precipitation. However, Agarwal et al. [ 10] did not find ethane formation using a catalyst prepared by ion exchange. Apparently, in addition to the reactor temperature, the presence of a support and the method of catalyst preparation affect the selectivity considerably. However, the presence of diluting silica does not lead to increased formation of ethane. Only the support surface in direct contact with the copper crystallites plays a role and the method of preparation apparently enlarges the number of acid sites. The catalytic steps of ester hydrogenolysis to alcohols are thought to proceed on copper metal [ 8,9 ] . Ethane formation may occur by a dehydration reaction followed by hydrogenation of the alkene and by hydrogenolysis of the carbon-oxygen sigma bond, but taking into account the Raney copper results, the metallic phase is not likely to be responsible for that. Moreover, a dehydration of an alcohol requires abstraction of a /3-hydrogen, but in the case of hydrogen abstraction on copper there is a preference for the abstraction of an ahydrogen [24,25] and subsequent formation of an aldehyde. In addition to copper metal, oxidic copper present due to incomplete reduction and the carrier surface might have an effect on the selectivity. Both of them can be titrated by the chemisorption of ammonia, but it was discussed before that in the current situation the main contribution is made by the support. In another paper [ 3 ] the formation of ethane was found to be connected with the formation of ethene and diethyl ether. The silica support has a major influence, as catalysts supported on Aerosil 200 (Degussa) exhibit a lower ethane formation than catalysts supported on silica S980A (Shell). Since zinc oxide is able to neutralize acid sites possibly present on the support, these observations point to the dehydration reaction as the most likely mechanism. Also for unpromoted CU/Si02 catalysts, this dehydration reaction is thought to proceed on acid sites on the support. The increase in the normalized ammonia chemisorption with the increase of the ethane selectivity supports the view of the dehydration on acid surface sites being responsible for the formation of ethane. Accordingly, the formation of ethene and ethane from ethanol is proposed to start with the dehydration of ethanol on acid sites: CH3 CH2 OH - CHZ=CHZ + HZ O Subsequently the ethene can be converted to ethane by hydrogenation on copper metal: CHZ=CHZ + Hz - CH3-CH3 For the silica-supported copper catalysts described in this paper, the combined action of acid sites and copper metal is proposed to catalyze the overall reaction from ethanol to ethane. 4. Conclusions In the characterization of a series of silica-supported copper catalysts prepared by homogeneous precipitation linear relations were found between the BET area and the copper 76 F.Th. van de Scheur et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 111 (1994) 63-77 content and between the copper content and the copper metal surface area. These are indications of a uniform structure independent of the copper loading. The BET areas after reduction at 643 K are approximately equal to the areas of the precursors. Another linear relation was found between the amounts of chemisorbed ammonia and the BET areas, which is thought to originate from the adsorption onto acid sites. Normalized on the quantity of copper, lower-loaded catalysts chemisorb relatively more ammonia. This is consistent with the hypothesis of more exposed support surface playing a significant role in the selectivity. In agreement with earlier findings on structure sensitivity, the activity of a 26 wt.-% Cu/ Si02 catalyst in the hydrogenolysis of methyl acetate was found to be independent of reduction temperature in the range 543-743 K and the corresponding copper metal areas. The reaction does apparently not proceed on a part of the copper surface, i.e. not on highly dispersed crystallites, and the active phase formed below 543 K seems to be responsible for the activity. It is interesting to note that both after reduction at 543 K and after reduction at 643 K, there is a linear correlation between copper loading and the metal surface area (cf. Fig. 3) . When varying the copper loading and keeping the weight of copper in the reactor constant at the same time, the activity of the catalysts was approximately independent of the copper loading, which is expected from the uniform structure found in adsorption experiments. However, the selectivity based on the amount of copper shows a different behaviour as higher amounts of ethane are formed on catalysts of low copper loading. The connection between the uptake of ammonia and the selectivity suggests that a dehydration reaction on acid sites at the carrier surface governs the formation of ethene, which is subsequently hydrogenated on copper to ethane. 5. The activity and selectivity of silica-supported copper catalysts in the hydrogenolysis of methyl acetate were studied in relation to the structure of the active phase. The activity was found independent of the copper loading, when the weight of copper in the reactor was kept constant. Copper catalysts were prepared by homogeneous precipitation. In the range of reduction temperatures between 543 K and 743 K, the activity was constant, in spite of considerably different copper metal surface areas. The absence of a correlation between activity and copper surface area is assigned to the formation of highly dispersed copper not active in methyl acetate hydrogenolysis. In contrast to the equal activity, catalysts of low copper loading produced more ethane than the higher loaded catalysts, based on the weight of copper. A remarkable parallel between the amount of ammonia chemisorbed on the reduced catalyst and the ethane selectivity suggests that a dehydration reaction to ethene on acid sites located at the silica support, followed by hydrogenation on the copper metal phase, is responsible for the formation of ethane.
